name.local_name: Uji wa Mchele na Mtoro wa Nyama

description: A silky, smooth, and deeply savory rice porridge made by slow-simmering rice in a rich, homemade beef stock until it breaks down into a comforting, gruel-like consistency. Topped with seasoned beef and fresh aromatics.
origin_region: Adapted (Inspired by Asian Congee, using local Ugandan ingredients)

cultural_significance.cultural_notes: While not a traditional Ugandan dish, this version of congee fits perfectly into the local cuisine's philosophy of creating nourishing, easy-to-digest meals. It is similar in spirit to other local porridges (uji) and is an excellent way to use beef bones and leftover rice for a soothing, restorative dish.

ingredients.name: Beef Bones (with some meat)
ingredients.notes: Marrow bones or soup bones work best

ingredients.name: Short-Grain Rice or Jasmine Rice
ingredients.notes: Washed thoroughly (or use 3 cups of cooked rice for a quicker version)

ingredients.name: Fresh Ginger
ingredients.notes: 1 piece smashed for stock, 2 pieces julienned for garnish

ingredients.name: Garlic
ingredients.notes: 2 cloves smashed for stock, 2 cloves minced for beef

ingredients.name: Spring Onions
ingredients.notes: Sliced, white and green parts separated

steps.instruction: Make the beef stock: Place the beef bones in the large stockpot. Cover with 12 cups of cold water. Add the smashed ginger and garlic cloves, and the white parts of the spring onions. Bring to a boil.
Once boiling, reduce heat to low, skim off any scum that rises to the surface. Cover and let it simmer gently for a minimum of 1 hour (2-3 hours is ideal for a richer stock).

cooking_indicators.visual: The liquid will reduce slightly and become a rich, golden color.
cooking_indicators.texture: Meat on the bones should be very tender.

steps.instruction: Strain the stock through a fine sieve into a clean pot. Reserve the tender meat from the bones, shred it, and set aside. Discard the bones and aromatics.
You should have about 8-10 cups of rich beef stock. Return it to the clean pot. Add the washed, uncooked rice to the hot stock. (If using cooked rice, add it now).

Bring the mixture to a boil, then reduce the heat to the lowest possible setting. Partially cover the pot and let it simmer very gently for about 1 hour, stirring occasionally to prevent the rice from sticking to the bottom.

cooking_indicators.visual: The rice grains will burst and the mixture will thicken to a creamy, porridge-like consistency.

steps.instruction: While the congee is cooking, prepare the beef topping. Heat vegetable oil in a small skillet. Saut√© the minced garlic and julienned ginger for 30 seconds. Add the shredded beef and 1 tablespoon of soy sauce. Stir-fry for 2-3 minutes until fragrant. Set aside.
Once the congee has reached your desired consistency, season it with the remaining soy sauce and salt to taste.
Ladle the hot congee into bowls. Top with the seasoned beef, green parts of the spring onions, and fresh cilantro.
Serve immediately with lime wedges on the side for squeezing over the top.

serving_suggestions: Serve as a complete, comforting meal. Traditional condiments include extra soy sauce, chili oil, or a drizzle of sesame oil. In Uganda, a side of steamed greens (Sukuma Wiki) would complement it well.
